title: 114_hr4042
content: The Act may be cited as the "Pre-K for USA Act." Key findings are included in the Act. The "Pre-K for USA Act" findings highlight the benefits of high-quality prekindergarten programs, including improved academic success, reduced need for other services, lower likelihood of criminal behavior, and increased college attendance. Despite these advantages, many school districts do not offer prekindergarten programs. In Texas, many school districts offer only part-day prekindergarten programs, missing out on potential Federal funding. State budget cuts in 2011 eliminated grants for expanding half-day to full-day programs. Local governments stepped in to fund full-day prekindergarten programs due to education funding cuts. Direct application for Federal funding would benefit localities. SEC. 3. PREKINDERGARTEN DEVELOPMENT GRANTS. The Secretary of Education, in consultation with the Secretary of Health and Human Services, will award competitive grants to increase capacity for high-quality prekindergarten programs. Grants will be awarded for up to 3 years and applications must be submitted by Governors or chief executive officers of eligible entities. States must consult with the State Advisory Council on Early Childhood Education and Care when developing their grant applications. To be eligible for a grant under this Act, a State, local educational agency, or other local government entity must contribute non-Federal matching funds equal to at least 20 percent of the grant amount. These funds can come from State funding, local funding, philanthropy, in-kind contributions, or a combination of resources. The Secretary may waive or reduce the matching funds requirement for entities facing financial hardship. The Secretary may waive or reduce the matching funds requirement for entities facing financial hardship when applying for a grant. Grant recipients can use funds to award subgrants to eligible local entities. The Secretary cannot award a subgrant if the program has already received funding in the same fiscal year. Authorization of appropriations is provided for carrying out this section. Authorization of appropriations for this section includes $750,000,000 for fiscal year 2016 and necessary sums for fiscal years 2017 through 2025. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "eligible local entity" refers to local educational agencies, early childhood education programs, or consortia of these entities. "Full-day" means a day equivalent to a full school day in the state and not less than 5 hours. "High-quality prekindergarten program" is a program supported by an eligible local entity. A high-quality prekindergarten program supported by an eligible local entity must serve children aged 3 or 4, or those who have attained the legal age for State-funded prekindergarten. It also requires teachers to have a bachelor's degree in early childhood education or a related field. Teachers in a high-quality prekindergarten program must have a bachelor's degree in early childhood education or a related field. They also need to demonstrate knowledge through a State-approved assessment, engage in ongoing professional development for at least 2 years, and be enrolled in an educator preparation program for not more than 3 years. Alternatively, teachers can have a bachelor's degree in any field with a credential, license, or endorsement showing competence. (C) Maintains a maximum class size of 20 children and a child to instructional staff ratio of 10 to 1. (E) Offers a full-day program with developmentally appropriate learning environments and evidence-based curricula aligned with State standards. (G) Provides instructional staff salaries comparable to K-12 teaching staff and ensures ongoing monitoring and program evaluation for continuous improvement. (I) Offers comprehensive services including screenings for vision, dental, health, and development. The curr_chunk focuses on providing family engagement opportunities, nutrition services, and support services for children and their families. This includes parent conferences, parent education, nutritious meals aligned with guidelines, and nutrition education. The curr_chunk focuses on providing programs for children with disabilities, including educational programs, physical activity programs, and additional support services based on needs analysis. Professional development is also emphasized. The curr_chunk emphasizes high-quality professional development for staff, meeting education performance standards, and maintaining evidence-based health and safety standards. It also defines terms related to education and the Secretary of Education.
